[4](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-4-135614300)

This ecumenical pro-jihadist policy was somewhat complicated by [Iran’s role in Syria](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2015/01/29/americas-silent-partnership-with-iran-and-the-contest-for-middle-eastern-order-part-two/)
 since 2011, but even in the wake of that hecatomb, in the present atmosphere of heightened religious sectarianism, Iran’s regime maintains the policy in outline, from [HAMAS](https://www.aspistrategist.org.au/irans-role-in-the-latest-gaza-conflict/)
 to [Al-Qaeda](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2018/10/26/examining-irans-long-relationship-with-al-qaeda/)
.

[5](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-5-135614300)

Iran’s regime [changed](https://www.irishtimes.com/news/tehran-renames-street-to-improve-egypt-ties-1.965436)
 the name of “Khaled Islambuli Street” in January 2004 as part of an effort to improve relations with the Egyptian government. The new name was “Intifada Street”, a reference to the then-ongoing terrorist war Yasser Arafat’s Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) was waging against Israel—with [extensive support](https://aijac.org.au/op-ed/irans-multifront-war-against-israel-is-decades-old/)
 from the Iranian theocracy.

[6](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-6-135614300)

Oved Lobel (2021, August 4), ‘The Graveyard of Empires: The Causes and Consequences of American Withdrawal from Afghanistan’, _European Eye on Radicalization_ Report, pp. 9-13. [Available here](https://eeradicalization.com/afghanistan-report-three-jihads-us-withdrawal-and-delusions-oved-lobel/)
.

[7](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-7-135614300)

Christine Fair (2014), _Fighting to the End: The Pakistan Army’s Way of War_, p. 82.

[8](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-8-135614300)

For the most thorough overview, see: Chris Sands and Fazelminallah Qazizai (2019), _Night Letters: Gulbuddin Hekmatyar and the Afghan Islamists Who Changed the World_.

[9](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-9-135614300)

Thomas Hegghammer (2020), _The Caravan: Abdallah Azzam and the Rise of Global Jihad_, p. 365.

[10](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-10-135614300)

[The 9/11 Commission Report](https://www.9-11commission.gov/report/911Report.pdf)
 (2004), p. 467. Al-Zawahiri’s memoir, published in 2001 was entitled, “Knights Under the Prophet’s Banner” (_Fursan Taht Rayah al-Nabi_).

[11](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-11-135614300)

_The Caravan_, p. 329.

[12](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-12-135614300)

_The Caravan_, pp. 351-52.

[13](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-13-135614300)

Bin Laden had been moved to create the Masada camp after the humiliating fiasco at Zhawar in April 1986, which disclosed how badly organised and incapable the Arab-Afghan fighters were. In April 1987, the Arab-Afghans endured what might most accurately be described as a less-bad defeat at the battle at Jaji: the Mujahideen (just about) held off one of the Soviet “retreating offensive” incursions, but the Arabs got mauled and forced to retreat. Still, it wasn’t quite the decimation of a year earlier, and Bin Laden—who personally fought at Jaji—ascribed the improvement, naturally, to the training at Masada. In casting the Arabs at Jaji as partaking in glorious victory, Bin Laden was helped by the daily dispatches of Jamal Khashoggi, and Bin Laden’s star was born in the Arab world. It was this moment in the spring of 1987 that Mustafa Hamid identifies as “the main cause of Al-Qaeda’s emergence as a separate organisation, and its rapid growth.” Hamid adds that Bin Laden’s money also played a significant role, since most other factions were broke by this point. See: Mustafa Hamid and Leah Farrall (2015), _The Arabs at War in Afghanistan_, p. 111.

[14](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-14-135614300)

The best book on Al-Qaeda’s longstanding entanglement with “the Haqqani Network” is: Don Rassler and Vahid Brown (2014), _Fountainhead of Jihad: The Haqqani Nexus, 1973-2012_.

[15](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-15-135614300)

The Egyptians closest to Bin Laden seem to have been: [Ali Amin al-Rashidi](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2018/02/05/al-qaedas-first-military-emir/)
 (Abu Ubayda al-Panjshiri), [Muhammad Atef](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2018/02/05/profile-of-a-9-11-planner-muhammad-atef/)
 (Abu Hafs al-Masri), and Sayyed Imam al-Sharif (Dr. Fadl)—rather than Al-Zawahiri. Al-Sharif was close to Al-Zawahiri, though neither of them were major figures in the Arab-Afghan population. The narrative that “evil Egyptians” led Bin Laden astray in the late 1980s might have partly originated in a post-9/11 effort by Azzam’s partisans and/or the Saudi government to rewrite the history to make themselves look better. The main aspect, however, seems to be some Western authors and journalists having “overdramatized the intrigues in Peshawar”, where there really was “bad blood between Abdallah Azzam and some of the Egyptians”. _The Caravan_, pp. 359-61.

[16](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-16-135614300)

Azzam, though not a member of Al-Qaeda, was “not a very active opponent”: he largely did not understand what it was and where it was going, but his tendency to avoid intra-Muslim conflict meant Azzam generally did not oppose developments within the Arab-Afghan population, and was not displeased at the special forces-like capacity Al-Qaeda was providing to the Arab-Afghans \[_The Caravan_, p. 361\]. Minutes from a meeting in August 1988 are sometimes held up as the founding of Al-Qaeda. What those minutes actually show is Al-Qaeda as a pre-existing organisation, and an effort to poach from Azzam’s cadre—albeit subtly, since one of Azzam’s key lieutenants, Tamim al-Adnani, was present \[_The Arabs at War in Afghanistan_, pp. 108-12\]. In other words, Bin Laden was competing with Azzam, even if Azzam was not aware of it.

[17](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-17-135614300)

Donald Holbrook (2014), _The Al-Qaeda Doctrine: The Framing and Evolution of the Leadership’s Public Discourse_, p. 82.

[18](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-18-135614300)

Lawrence Wright (2006), _The Looming Tower: Al-Qaeda’s Road to 9/11_, pp. 157-59.

[19](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-19-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 57.

[20](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-20-135614300)

The exact timeline of Bin Laden’s arrival in Sudan is somewhat contested. The 9/11 Commission Report simply says: “Bin Ladin moved to Sudan in 1991”. Other sources than the link cited above give the arrival date as December 1991, for example, _A History of Modern Sudan_ (2008), by Robert Collins (p. 196), which describes Bin Laden being received “enthusiastically” by Al-Turabi. There are claims for other dates, both later (January 1992 seems to be quite a common one) and earlier—Dwight Hamilton and Kostas Rimsa claim (p. 94) in, _Terror Threat: International and Homegrown Terrorists and Their Threat to Canada_ (2007), that Bin Laden was “fully established” in Sudan by mid-September 1991—but the sourcing for these is less credible.

[21](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-21-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 57.

[22](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-22-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 57.

[23](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-23-135614300)

Kyle Orton (2023, February 23), ‘Is Al-Qaeda Capable of Global Terrorism Any More?’, _European Eye on Radicalization_ Report, p. 14. [Available here](https://eeradicalization.com/al-qaeda-global-terrorism-report-kyle-orton/)
.

[24](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-24-135614300)

John Schindler (2007), _Unholy Terror: Bosnia, Al-Qaida, and the Rise of Global Jihad_, p. 123.

[25](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-25-135614300)

For the earliest and most comprehensive documentation of the nature of the Huthis, see: Oved Lobel (2021, March 24), ‘Becoming Ansar Allah: How the Islamic Revolution Conquered Yemen’, _European Eye on Radicalization_ Report. [Available here](https://eeradicalization.com/becoming-ansar-allah-islamic-revolution-yemen-oved-lobel/)
.

[26](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-26-135614300)

Ibrahim al-Banna [also used](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2015/12/an-al-qaeda-commander-comes-out-from-the-shadows.php)
 the names “Ibrahim Abu Salih” and “Abu al-Hassan al-Hashemi”.

[27](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-27-135614300)

The story of Ibrahim al-Banna in Yemen highlights not only the Qaeda-Iran relationship, but the [ambiguous role of the Yemeni government](https://foreignpolicy.com/2012/08/29/whose-side-is-yemen-on/)
 under Ali Abdullah Saleh when it came to fighting the jihadists. Al-Banna was arrested in August 2010 in Yemen—it is from [the transcripts](https://www.aberfoylesecurity.com/?p=2038)
 of his interrogation that we know how early he established Al-Qaeda’s relations with the Huthis—but he was released _very_ quickly. This kind of catch-and-release, as well as the mysterious jailbreaks, were a feature of the Saleh government’s “War on Terror” policy.

[28](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-28-135614300)

For the full story, see: Thomas Hegghammer (2010), _Jihad in Saudi Arabia: Violence and Pan-Islamism Since 1979_.

[29](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-29-135614300)

The [transcripts from Al-Banna’s brief detention](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/01/state-department-designates-founding-member-of-al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula.php)
 in 2010 have him explaining his relationship with [Abdul Munim al-Badawi](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2017/01/25/the-islamic-states-first-war-minister/)
 (Abu Hamza al-Muhajir), another Muslim Brotherhood and EIJ veteran, the deputy and “war minister” for the Islamic State when it was [first declared in 2006](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2018/03/18/the-announcement-of-the-islamic-state-in-2006/)
, and a key part of the stitching that bound Al-Qaeda to its Iraqi affiliate before and after [the years of overt loyalty](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2016/08/30/the-islamic-states-relationship-with-al-qaeda/)
 from 2004 to 2006. Al-Badawi moved to Iraq in 2002, part of the Al-Qaeda cell that set up in Saddam’s Baghdad that spring, and [remained in contact](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/01/state-department-designates-founding-member-of-al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula.php)
 with Al-Banna afterwards: Al-Banna says he pushed for Al-Badawi’s promotion within Al-Qaeda in Mesopotamia, and, interestingly, it [seems](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/01/state-department-designates-founding-member-of-al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula.php)
 Al-Banna was behind the confusion over Al-Badawi’s real identity, convincing Al-Badawi to adopt the _kunya_ “Abu Ayyub al-Masri”. By all accounts, Al-Banna and Al-Badawi were close socially as well as ideologically and organisationally, having [run Al-Qaeda’s operations together](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/01/state-department-designates-founding-member-of-al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula.php)
 for two years, from 1996 to 1998, and Al-Banna’s devotion to Al-Zawahiri appears absolute. Al-Banna (and Al-Badawi) were appointed leaders in Yemen [by Al-Zawahiri](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/01/state-department-designates-founding-member-of-al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula.php)
 in the 1990s, and in 2006 Al-Banna unhesitatingly stepped down as emir from what was not-yet called AQAP to make way for Nasir al-Wuhayshi after he had been freed in one of those Yemeni jailbreaks. Al-Banna [worked in Yemen](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2017/01/state-department-designates-founding-member-of-al-qaeda-in-the-arabian-peninsula.php)
 with Muhammad al-Zawahiri, brother of the departed Al-Qaeda emir, and [Ahmad Mabruk](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2016/10/04/al-qaeda-in-syria-and-american-policy/)
, also an EIJ veteran, who accompanied the good doctor on the 1995 Russia trip and was a major jihadist figure in his own right. [Another of AQAP’s accounts](https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2015/12/an-al-qaeda-commander-comes-out-from-the-shadows.php)
 tells of Al-Banna having been imprisoned in the late 1980s with another EIJ operative, Mustafa Abu al-Yazid (Saeed al-Masri), who had served time earlier in the 1980s, presumably simultaneous with if not alongside Al-Zawahiri, as part of the post-Sadat crackdown. Al-Yazid was Al-Qaeda’s financial emir at the time of 9/11 and rose to be number three in the organisation by about 2007, [appointed](https://www.bbc.com/news/10206180)
 to oversee the war in Afghanistan and as Bin Laden’s chief of staff. Al-Yazid was [killed](https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/01/world/asia/01qaeda.html)
 in a drone strike in May 2010 and replaced by a Libyan, Jamal al-Misrati (Atiyya). Al-Yazid had been one of the point-men handling AQC’s relations with the IS movement. Al-Yazid [instructed Samir Hijazi](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2015/09/14/al-qaeda-central-in-syria/)
 (Faruq al-Suri) to go to Baghdad in early 2002, for example. (Hijazi broke with IS and [currently leads](https://kyleorton.substack.com/p/reduced-but-rebuilding-united-nations)
 Al-Qaeda’s overt presence in Syria.) Al-Yazid [met Abd al-Rahman al-Qaduli](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/the-islamic-states-official-biography-abd-al-rahman-al-qaduli-abu-ali-al-anbari)
 (Abu Ali al-Anbari), the de facto deputy of what was then-AQM, when Al-Qaduli travelled—via Iran—to Pakistan in February 2006, four months before Al-Qaduli was captured in Iraq. And even after IS formally dissolved its Al-Qaeda ties, Al-Yazid was [involved in sending](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2014/05/03/al-qaeda-provides-evidence-isis-was-its-iraqi-branch-calls-for-it-to-return/)
 instructions to the group’s leaders in Iraq to tell them to desist from certain “political gaffes”. A [number](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2017/11/21/al-qaeda-instructs-the-islamic-states-predecessor-not-to-attack-iran/)
 of [letters](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2018/02/06/al-qaeda-letter-on-relations-with-the-islamic-state-and-iran/)
 have been found from after IS supposedly broke with Al-Qaeda in 2006 containing instructions to IS—often to leave Iran alone—and IS’s most famous spokesman, Taha Falaha (Abu Muhammad al-Adnani), [confirmed](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2014/05/13/isiss-spokesman-denounces-al-qaedas-leader-claims-isis-is-the-victim/)
 IS “kept abiding by the advice and guidance” until the rancorous split in 2013-14.

[30](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-30-135614300)

Adrian Levy and Catherine Scott-Clark (2017), _The Exile: The Stunning Inside Story of Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda in Flight_, p. 44.

[31](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-31-135614300)

Stephen Hayes (2004), _The Connection: How al-Qaeda’s Collaboration With Saddam Hussein Has Endangered America_, pp. 103-04.

[32](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-32-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 66.

[33](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-33-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 66.

[34](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-34-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 66.

[35](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-35-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, pp. 133-34.

[36](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-36-135614300)

Brynjar Lia (2007), _Architect of Global Jihad: The Life of Al-Qaida Strategist Abu Mus’ab al-Suri_, p. 287.

[37](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-37-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 151.

[38](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-38-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 147.

[39](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-39-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 148.

[40](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-40-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 149.

[41](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-41-135614300)

Ibid.

[42](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-42-135614300)

Ibid.

[43](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-43-135614300)

_The Exile_, p. 14.

[44](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-44-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 155.

[45](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-45-135614300)

The 9/11 Commission Report (p. 532) notes that KSM claimed Al-Zawahiri was opposed to the 9/11 attacks, imploring Bin Laden to adhere to Taliban emir Mullah Muhammad Umar’s injunction after the Embassy bombings against using Afghanistan as a base to attack the U.S., but “other detainees” said Al-Zawahiri was “squarely behind” Bin Laden, which seems to be the truth. It is possible KSM was trying to exclude other jihadists from “credit” for the “Planes Operation”.

[46](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-46-135614300)

_The Exile_, p. 44.

[47](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-47-135614300)

_The Exile_, pp. 45-7.

[48](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-48-135614300)

9/11 Commission Report, p. 332.

[49](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-49-135614300)

_The Exile_, pp. 147-48.

[50](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-50-135614300)

_The Exile_, pp. 159-60.

[51](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-51-135614300)

_The Exile_, pp. 235-40.

[52](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-52-135614300)

Lobel, ‘The Graveyard of Empires’, pp. 6-7, 23.

[53](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-53-135614300)

_The Exile_, p. 495.

[54](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-54-135614300)

The first use of the “ninja missile” was in Syria, in February 2017, to kill Al-Zawahiri’s then-deputy, [Abu al-Khayr](https://kyleorton.co.uk/2017/02/27/al-qaedas-deputy-killed-in-syria/)
. At the time, those of us watching Syria knew that something was different about the strike—Abu al-Khayr’s car was still intact, except for a section of roof on one side—and then it happened several more times. It [took two years](https://www.wsj.com/articles/secret-u-s-missile-aims-to-kill-only-terrorists-not-nearby-civilians-11557403411)
 for a public explanation.

[55](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-55-135614300)

United Nations Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team Report, 13 February 2023, p. 3. [Available here](https://kyleorton1991.files.wordpress.com/2023/02/analytical-support-and-sanctions-monitoring-team-13-february-2023.pdf)
.

[56](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-56-135614300)

Brian Fishman (2016), _The Master Plan: ISIS, Al-Qaeda, and the Jihadi Strategy for Final Victory_, p. 38.

[57](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-57-135614300)

That said, Ansaru—the Al-Qaeda faction in Nigeria—did go out of its way to [issue a statement](https://jamestown.org/program/islamic-state-propaganda-renews-focus-on-africa-but-a-jihadist-monopoly-remains-elusive/)
 defending Sayf, specifically from the charges of being an Iranian puppet, about three weeks before Al-Zawahiri was killed.

[58](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-58-135614300)

The other most obvious candidate after Sayf is **Muhammad Abbatay (Abd al-Rahman al-Maghrebi)**, Al-Zawahiri’s son-in-law, who is also in Iran. **Yasin al-Suri**, another serious contended, is in Iran, too.

[59](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-59-135614300)

Gregg Carlstrom, the Middle East correspondent at _The_ _Economist_, [memorably tweeted](https://twitter.com/glcarlstrom/status/1554219194127990788)
: “Zawahiri will be best remembered for transforming al-Qaeda from a feared terrorist franchise into a really boring podcast”.

[60](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-60-135614300)

A U.S. National Security Council official [said on background](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/press-briefings/2022/08/01/background-press-call-by-a-senior-administration-official-on-a-u-s-counterterrorism-operation/)
: “\[Al-Zawahiri\] used his authority across Al-Qaeda’s global network of regional affiliates and followers to provide strategic direction and continually urging attacks on the United States and reinforcing the prioritization of the United States as Al-Qaeda’s primary enemy. … He built an organizational model that allowed him to lead the global network, even from relative isolation. And he was one of the last remaining figures who carried this kind of \[status\] significance”.

[61](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-61-135614300)

Lobel, ‘The Graveyard of Empires’, pp. 6, 23.

[62](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-62-135614300)

On 29 July 2022, Siraj gave an [interview to an Indian outlet](https://www.news18.com/news/world/exclusive-afghanistan-needs-indias-help-desperately-to-secure-peaceful-environment-taliban-interior-minister-haqqani-5670295.html)
 saying: “Al-Qaeda … has no presence in Afghanistan and is no more of a threat and the world should not feel threatened about the already dead outfit.” It’s obviously amusing enough given Al-Zawahiri being killed in Kabul two days later, and more so once it is understood that Siraj is also a member of Al-Qaeda and was speaking from Afghanistan.

[63](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-63-135614300)

Carlotta Gall’s _The Wrong Enemy: America in Afghanistan, 2001-2014_ goes as far as one can on the present evidence in describing Pakistan’s concealment of Bin Laden up to 2011. Whether ever detail transpires to be true on that specific issue, it is an excellent description of the shameful situation the West got into in Afghanistan, paying Pakistan to pretend to help us, as it barely concealed the fact it orchestrated the jihadist mayhem that killed our soldiers and thousands of Afghan civilians. In terms of last year, the White House spokesman was asked whether Pakistan had been warned about the drone heading for Al-Zawahiri, and [pointedly responded](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/press-briefings/2022/08/02/press-briefing-by-press-secretary-karine-jean-pierre-and-nsc-coordinator-for-strategic-communications-john-kirby-august-2-2022/)
, “There were no notifications in advance”. Any such notification to Pakistan would have led to Al-Qaeda’s leader being tipped off.

[64](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad#footnote-anchor-64-135614300)

Biden made a [strange statement](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2023/06/30/remarks-by-president-biden-on-the-supreme-courts-decision-on-the-administrations-student-debt-relief-program/)
 (even stranger if you see the video) on 30 June: “Do you remember what I said about Afghanistan? I said Al-Qaeda would not be there. I said it wouldn’t be there. I said we’d get help from the Taliban. What’s happening now? What’s going on? Read your press. I was right.” The “help from the Taliban” line was particularly odd, since Biden had needed to order the strike on Al-Zawahiri precisely because the Taliban were _not_ helping against Al-Qaeda, and were in fact harbouring its leader in their capital. In the year since, the evidence has piled up all in the same direction. The U.N. Monitoring Team report in June painted an alarming picture of what the ISI network is doing in Afghanistan—and makes clear that it is all components of that network: “The link between the Taliban and both Al-Qaida and Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) \[the ‘Pakistani Taliban’\] remains strong and symbiotic. A range of terrorist groups have greater freedom of manoeuvre under the Taliban … They are making good use of this, and the threat of terrorism is rising in both Afghanistan and the region”. Etc. Etc. A decent summary of the report is [available here](https://www.aspistrategist.org.au/un-warns-of-risk-of-terrorism-from-afghanistan/)
.

5

[](https://www.kyleorton.com/p/ayman-al-zawahiri-life-in-jihad/comments)

It mentions that al-Zawahiri was killed in an airstrike in Kabul, Afghanistan, on July 31, 2022. <image:26> The article also mentions that the house where al-Zawahiri was killed was in the Sherpur area of Kabul. The article also mentions that the Haqqani Network, a group within the Taliban, is closely tied to the ISI, which means Pakistan's military-intelligence establishment knew where Al-Qaeda's leader was and tried to shield him from America.

* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.

* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.



## Decision Options
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record

Claim: "<image:26> This image shows the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. This is how a precision strike looks like: a single missile through the window, and only Haniyeh and his bodyguard are dead. Nobody else in the building is even injured."

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. This is how a precision strike looks like: a single missile through the window, and only Haniyeh and his bodyguard are dead. Nobody else in the building is even injured."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:26>)
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The image <image:26>

## Elaboration
I am sorry, but I am unable to verify the claim. The evidence consists only of the image itself. I need additional information to verify the claim, such as news reports or other sources that describe the event.


# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
web_search("Ismail Haniyeh assassination July 31 2024")
web_search("Hamas leader killed July 31 2024")
```
_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. This is how a precision strike looks like: a single missile through the window, and only Haniyeh and his bodyguard are dead. Nobody else in the building is even injured."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:26>)
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The image <image:26>

## Elaboration
I am sorry, but I am unable to verify the claim. The evidence consists only of the image itself. I need additional information to verify the claim, such as news reports or other sources that describe the event.


## Actions
```
web_search("Ismail Haniyeh assassination July 31 2024")
web_search("Hamas leader killed July 31 2024")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh): 
Content: "[Jump to content](#bodyContent)

[Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system")
: [35°49′10″N 51°24′57″E﻿ / ﻿35.81944°N 51.41583°E﻿ / 35.81944; 51.41583](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh&params=35_49_10_N_51_24_57_E_)

[![Extended-protected article](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8c/Extended-protection-shackle.svg/20px-Extended-protection-shackle.svg.png)](/wiki/Wikipedia:Protection_policy#extended "This article is extended-confirmed-protected")

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

2024 assassination of Hamas leader in Tehran, Iran

| Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh |     |
| --- | --- |
| Part of the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")<br>, the [2024 Iran–Israel conflict](/wiki/2024_Iran%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "2024 Iran–Israel conflict")<br>, and the [Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)](/wiki/Middle_Eastern_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)") |     |
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Pij_hani_14030509_0357236_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Pij_hani_14030509_0357236_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pij_hani_14030509_0357236_(cropped).jpg)<br><br>Haniyeh (left) meeting with the [Supreme Leader of Iran](/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran "Supreme Leader of Iran")<br> [Ali Khamenei](/wiki/Ali_Khamenei "Ali Khamenei")<br> (right) hours before his death |     |

| Location | [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")<br>, [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") |
| [Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system") | [35°49′10″N 51°24′57″E﻿ / ﻿35.81944°N 51.41583°E﻿ / 35.81944; 51.41583](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh&params=35_49_10_N_51_24_57_E_) |
| Date | 31 July 2024  <br>~2:00 a.m.[\[1\]](#cite_note-time-1)<br> ([IRST](/wiki/Iran_Standard_Time "Iran Standard Time")<br>) |
| Target | [Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Ismail_Haniyeh "Ismail Haniyeh")<br> [**X**](/wiki/Assassination "Assassination") |
| Attack type | [Explosion](/wiki/Explosion "Explosion")<br> or [projectile attack](/wiki/Projectile "Projectile")<br> (disputed)[\[a\]](#cite_note-4) |
| Deaths | Ismail Haniyeh  <br>Wassim Abu Shaaban |
| Perpetrator | ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Flag_of_Israel.svg/40px-Flag_of_Israel.svg.png)[Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") |

On 31 July 2024, [Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Ismail_Haniyeh "Ismail Haniyeh")
, the political leader of [Hamas](/wiki/Hamas "Hamas")
, was assassinated along with his personal bodyguard in the Iranian capital [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")
 by an [Israeli](/wiki/Israel "Israel")
 attack.[\[4\]](#cite_note-AP31july-5)
[\[5\]](#cite_note-:8-6)
 Haniyeh was killed in his accommodation in a military-run guesthouse after attending the inauguration ceremony for Iranian president [Masoud Pezeshkian](/wiki/Masoud_Pezeshkian "Masoud Pezeshkian")
.[\[6\]](#cite_note-reuters31july-7)
 [Nasser Kanaani](/wiki/Nasser_Kanaani "Nasser Kanaani")
, the spokesman of the [Ministry of Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Iran) "Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)")
 of [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran")
, condemned this assassination and said that Haniyeh's "blood will never be wasted".[\[7\]](#cite_note-aje.io-8)

The cause of Haniyeh's death is under investigation by Iran's [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps")
 (IRGC).[\[8\]](#cite_note-9)
 Differing reports emerged as to how he was killed, ranging from a missile strike[\[4\]](#cite_note-AP31july-5)
 to a remotely detonated explosive device previously hidden in his bedroom at the IRGC-run guesthouse.[\[2\]](#cite_note-:4-2)
 According to analysts, the assassination exposed critical security flaws.[\[9\]](#cite_note-nyt3aug-10)
[\[10\]](#cite_note-:9-11)
 The investigation has led to the arrest of over two dozen individuals, including senior intelligence and military officials, as well as staff from the guesthouse.[\[9\]](#cite_note-nyt3aug-10)

Haniyeh was a prominent figure within Hamas since the organization's founding in 1987. Haniyeh was the highest-ranking Hamas political leader killed since the start of the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")
.[\[11\]](#cite_note-wsj31july-12)

Background
----------

### Ismail Haniyeh

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/03-03-2020_Ismail_Haniyeh_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-03-03-2020_Ismail_Haniyeh_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:03-03-2020_Ismail_Haniyeh_(cropped).jpg)

, and a group of men posing with a model of the [Dome of the Rock](/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock "Dome of the Rock")
.[\[17\]](#cite_note-nyt30jul-18)

### Killings of Hamas officials

In response to the [October 7 attack](/wiki/October_7_attack "October 7 attack")
, Israel stated it would target Hamas leaders.[\[11\]](#cite_note-wsj31july-12)
 On 2 January 2024, Hamas deputy [Saleh al-Arouri](/wiki/Saleh_al-Arouri "Saleh al-Arouri")
 was [assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_Saleh_al-Arouri "Assassination of Saleh al-Arouri")
 in an airstrike in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut")
.[\[18\]](#cite_note-j076-19)
 On 13 July 2024, Israel attempted to assassinate Hamas military chief [Mohammed Deif](/wiki/Mohammed_Deif "Mohammed Deif")
, with the [Israel Defense Forces](/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces "Israel Defense Forces")
 announcing his death on 1 August.[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)
 Hours before Haniyeh's death, Israel announced the [assassination of Fuad Shukr](/wiki/Killing_of_Fuad_Shukr "Killing of Fuad Shukr")
, a senior [Hezbollah](/wiki/Hezbollah "Hezbollah")
 leader in Beirut.[\[11\]](#cite_note-wsj31july-12)

Assassination
-------------

The initial report of Ismail Haniyeh's killing emerged from Iran's [Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps](/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps "Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps")
 (IRGC), who provided limited specifics regarding the circumstances of his death, which it said occurred early on 31 July and indicated that the incident was under investigation. Ismail Haniyeh")
**

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/20px-Commons-logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Commons-logo.svg)
 Media related to [Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh "commons:Category:Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh")
 at Wikimedia Commons

[Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")

Part of the [Gaza–Israel conflict](/wiki/Gaza%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "Gaza–Israel conflict")
, the [Israeli–Palestinian conflict](/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict "Israeli–Palestinian conflict")
, and the [Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)](/wiki/Middle_Eastern_crisis_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Middle Eastern crisis (2023–present)")

| Released | *   [Yarden Roman-Gat](/wiki/Kidnapping_of_Yarden_Roman-Gat "Kidnapping of Yarden Roman-Gat")<br>    <br>*   [Mia Schem](/wiki/Kidnapping_of_Mia_Schem "Kidnapping of Mia Schem")<br>    <br>*   [Naama Levy](/wiki/Kidnapping_of_Naama_Levy "Kidnapping of Naama Levy")<br>    <br>*   [Liri Albag](/wiki/Liri_Albag "Liri Albag")<br>    <br>*   [Eli Sharabi](/wiki/Eli_Sharabi "Eli Sharabi")<br>    <br>*   [Edan Alexander](/wiki/Edan_Alexander "Edan Alexander")<br>    <br>*   [Omer Shem Tov](/wiki/Omer_Shem_Tov "Omer Shem Tov")<br>    <br>*   [Agam Berger](/wiki/Agam_Berger "Agam Berger")<br>    <br>*   [Emily Damari](/wiki/Emily_Damari "Emily Damari")<br>    <br>*   [Hanna Katzir](/wiki/Hanna_Katzir "Hanna Katzir") |
| Deceased | *   [Alex Dancyg](/wiki/Alex_Dancyg "Alex Dancyg")<br>    <br>*   [Hersh Goldberg-Polin](/wiki/Kidnapping_and_killing_of_Hersh_Goldberg-Polin "Kidnapping and killing of Hersh Goldberg-Polin")<br>    <br>*   [Alon Shamriz, Yotam Haim, and Samer Talalka](/wiki/Killing_of_Alon_Shamriz,_Yotam_Haim,_and_Samer_Talalka "Killing of Alon Shamriz, Yotam Haim, and Samer Talalka")<br>    <br>*   [Oded Lifshitz](/wiki/Oded_Lifshitz "Oded Lifshitz")<br>    <br>*   [Shani Louk](/wiki/Killing_of_Shani_Louk "Killing of Shani Louk")<br>    <br>*   [Bibas family](/wiki/Kidnapping_and_killing_of_the_Bibas_family "Kidnapping and killing of the Bibas family") |

Nations

Courts

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| Global courts | *   [_South Africa v. He also called for the Palestinian people to unite.[\[20\]](#cite_note-arabiya-21)
[\[85\]](#cite_note-89)
 Palestine's deputy permanent observer to the United Nations, Feda Abdelhady Nasser, called on the international community to stop Israel from dragging the Middle East into the "abyss".[\[86\]](#cite_note-unsc-90)
 Former [PLO](/wiki/Palestine_Liberation_Organization "Palestine Liberation Organization")
 member [Hanan Ashrawi](/wiki/Hanan_Ashrawi "Hanan Ashrawi")
 said that Israel's "gangster style" assassination of Haniyeh was made to "inflame the whole region".[\[87\]](#cite_note-91)

Hamas said that it mourned the death of Haniyeh, who it said was killed in "a treacherous Zionist raid on his residence".[\[88\]](#cite_note-x734-92)
 Senior Hamas official [Mousa Abu Marzook](/wiki/Mousa_Abu_Marzook "Mousa Abu Marzook")
 said that Haniyeh's assassination was "a cowardly act that will not pass in vain".[\[89\]](#cite_note-c729-93)
 Another senior official, [Sami Abu Zuhri](/wiki/Sami_Abu_Zuhri "Sami Abu Zuhri")
, accused Israel of killing Haniyeh, stating that it aims to break the will of Hamas and the Palestinians.[\[90\]](#cite_note-aljazeera.com-94)
 Hamas's military wing, the Al-Qassam Brigades, called the assassination a "dangerous event" that will have "major repercussions across the entire region".[\[91\]](#cite_note-95)

Palestinian Islamic Jihad released a statement saying that it "mourns with the Palestinian people and the Arab and [Islamic nation](/wiki/Ummah "Ummah")
" for the death of Haniyeh.[\[92\]](#cite_note-:0-96)

On 2 August, former [Grand Mufti of Jerusalem](/wiki/Grand_Mufti_of_Jerusalem "Grand Mufti of Jerusalem")
 Sheikh [Ekrima Sa'id Sabri](/wiki/Ekrima_Sa%27id_Sabri "Ekrima Sa'id Sabri")
 was arrested by Israeli police on suspicion of inciting "terrorism" after calling Haniyeh a "martyr" during a sermon in [East Jerusalem](/wiki/East_Jerusalem "East Jerusalem")
.[\[93\]](#cite_note-97)

### Iran

Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei held an emergency Supreme National Security Council meeting with top Iranian officials following the assassination.[\[17\]](#cite_note-nyt30jul-18)
 Khamenei later stated that "With this action, the criminal and [terrorist](/wiki/Israel_and_state-sponsored_terrorism "Israel and state-sponsored terrorism")
 [Zionist regime](/wiki/Zionist_regime "Zionist regime")
 prepared the ground for harsh punishment for itself, and we consider it our duty to seek revenge for his blood as he was [martyred](/wiki/Shahid "Shahid")
 in the territory of the Islamic Republic of Iran".[\[94\]](#cite_note-c453-98)
 _The New York Times_, citing Iranian officials, reported that he ordered direct strikes against Israel in response to the assassination.[\[43\]](#cite_note-nyt31jul-44)
[\[95\]](#cite_note-99)
 [Foreign Ministry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Iran) "Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)")
 spokesman [Nasser Kanaani](/wiki/Nasser_Kanaani "Nasser Kanaani")
 condemned the assassination, stating that Haniyeh's "blood will never be wasted".[\[7\]](#cite_note-aje.io-8)
 President Masoud Pezeshkian condemned the assassination and said Iran will defend its territorial integrity and make those responsible regret their actions.[\[4\]](#cite_note-AP31july-5)
 The government announced three days of public mourning for Haniyeh.[\[96\]](#cite_note-100)
 At the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations")
, Iran's ambassador [Amir Saeid Iravani](/wiki/Amir_Saeid_Iravani "Amir Saeid Iravani")
, called on the [UN Security Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security Council")
 to condemn Israel and said that Iran had a right to respond in self-defence to the killing, which he described as part of "Israel's decades-long pattern of terrorism and sabotage targeting Palestinians and other supporters of the Palestinian cause across the region and beyond." He also accused the United States of responsibility over the assassination.[\[86\]](#cite_note-unsc-90)
 The chief of staff of the [Iranian armed forces](/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Armed_Forces "Islamic Republic of Iran Armed Forces")
, [Mohammad Bagheri](/wiki/Mohammad_Bagheri_(general) "Mohammad Bagheri (general)")
, suggested that the response could come as part of a coordinated effort with the [Axis of Resistance](/wiki/Axis_of_Resistance "Axis of Resistance")
.[\[3\]](#cite_note-:7-3)

The [Tehran Stock Exchange](/wiki/Tehran_Stock_Exchange "Tehran Stock Exchange")
 fell 1.9%.[\[97\]](#cite_note-101)
 Iran's chief prosecutor warned journalists against "spreading rumours".[\[98\]](#cite_note-102)

A red flag was hoisted above the [Jamkaran Mosque](/wiki/Jamkaran_Mosque "Jamkaran Mosque")
 in [Qom](/wiki/Qom "Qom")
 and the [Milad Tower](/wiki/Milad_Tower "Milad Tower")
 in Tehran was lit up in red overnight.[\[3\]](#cite_note-:7-3)
 A large banner was placed in Tehran's Palestine Square, featuring a portrait of Haniyeh alongside the Dome of the Rock, with a message in [Farsi](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language")
 and [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language")
 reading: 'Wait for severe punishment.'"[\[99\]](#cite_note-103)

Opposition figures [Masih Alinejad](/wiki/Masih_Alinejad "Masih Alinejad")
, [Hamed Esmaeilion](/wiki/Hamed_Esmaeilion "Hamed Esmaeilion")
 and [Reza Pahlavi](/wiki/Reza_Pahlavi,_Crown_Prince_of_Iran "Reza Pahlavi, Crown Prince of Iran")
 called the killing of Haniyeh the sign of iniquity of the Iranian regime.[\[100\]](#cite_note-104)
[\[101\]](#cite_note-105)
[\[102\]](#cite_note-106)

### Israel

The Israel Defense Forces told [CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN")
 they "don't respond to reports in the foreign media".[\[103\]](#cite_note-107)
 The IDF did not release new security guidelines for civilians.[\[6\]](#cite_note-reuters31july-7)
 Heritage Minister [Amihai Eliyahu](/wiki/Amihai_Eliyahu "Amihai Eliyahu")
 praised the assassination, saying that it "makes the world a little better",[\[104\]](#cite_note-108)
[\[90\]](#cite_note-aljazeera.com-94)
 and that killing him was "the right way to cleanse the world from this filth."[\[105\]](#cite_note-109)
[\[106\]](#cite_note-110)
 Israel increased security measures at its diplomatic missions and Jewish sites worldwide.[\[107\]](#cite_note-111)
 The security of [Israel's delegation](/wiki/Israel_at_the_2024_Summer_Olympics "Israel at the 2024 Summer Olympics")
 in the [2024 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2024_Summer_Olympics "2024 Summer Olympics")
 was increased due to fears of potential attacks.[\[108\]](#cite_note-112)
 Then-Defense Minister [Yoav Gallant](/wiki/Yoav_Gallant "Yoav Gallant")
 addressed troops at an [Arrow](/wiki/Arrow_(missile_family) "Arrow (missile family)")
 missile air-defense battery, stating, "We don't want war, but we are preparing for all possibilities."[\[109\]](#cite_note-113)
 In December 2024, Defense Minister [Israel Katz](/wiki/Israel_Katz "Israel Katz")
 confirmed Israel's responsibility in the assassination of Haniyeh while delivering a threat to the Yemeni [Houthi movement](/wiki/Houthi_movement "Houthi movement")
, stating, "We will strike \[the Houthis'\] strategic infrastructure and decapitate its leaders. Just as we did to Haniyeh, [Sinwar](/wiki/Killing_of_Yahya_Sinwar "Killing of Yahya Sinwar")
, and [Nasrallah](/wiki/2024_Hezbollah_headquarters_strike "2024 Hezbollah headquarters strike")
, in Tehran, Gaza, and Lebanon—we will do in [Hodeidah](/wiki/Al_Hudaydah "Al Hudaydah")
 and [Sanaa](/wiki/Sanaa "Sanaa")
."[\[5\]](#cite_note-:8-6)
[\[110\]](#cite_note-114)

### International

The United Nations Security Council held an emergency session on 31 July following the assassination, during which China, Russia and Algeria condemned the killing. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731123456/https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/31/middleeast/analysis-iran-options-ismail-haniyeh-killing-intl/index.html)
     from the original on 31 July 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731041436/https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/hamas-political-leader-ismail-haniyeh-killed-in-iran-5723ad8b?mod=hp_lead_pos1)
     from the original on 31 July 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731034454/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/31/hamass-political-chief-ismail-haniyeh-assassinated-in-iran-state-media)
     from the original on 31 July 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240731040020/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/world-news/2024/07/31/israel-hamas-war-latest-news-leader-ismail-haniyeh-killed/)
     from the original on 31 July 2024."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Wikipedia article discusses the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, the political leader of Hamas, in Tehran, Iran, on July 31, 2024. The attack, attributed to Israel, resulted in Haniyeh's death along with his personal bodyguard. The article mentions differing reports on the method of the attack, including a missile strike or a remotely detonated explosive device. The article also includes reactions from various parties, including Hamas, Iran, and Israel. <image:26> is not present in the article.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp): 
Content: "[Skip to main content](#main-content)

Ismail Haniyeh’s Assassination: Escalation or an Off-Ramp?
==========================================================

     !Photo: Iranian Supreme Leader's Press Office via Getty Images <image:4045>

Photo: Iranian Supreme Leader's Press Office via Getty Images

*   [](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](https://x.com/intent/post?url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](mailto:?subject=Page from CSIS.org&body=https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp)
    
*   [](javascript:window.print())
    

Commentary by [Riley McCabe](/people/riley-mccabe)

Published August 1, 2024

Remote Visualization

Ismail Haniyeh, the head of Hamas’s political wing, was killed by an [explosion](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/01/world/middleeast/how-hamas-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-bomb.html)
 in his guesthouse in the Iranian capital of Tehran on July 31, 2024. Immediately following the assassination, Iranian supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a [statement](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/31/irans-khamenei-vows-harsh-punishment-for-israel-after-haniyeh-killing)
, “We consider it our duty to avenge his blood in this bitter and difficult incident that happened in the territory of the Islamic Republic.” In April and May 2024, Israel and Iran exchanged long-range strikes in a rare instance of direct confrontation between the two states. As journalist Oz Katerji [put it](https://twitter.com/OzKaterji/status/1818610790108135631)
, “Israel is now just one Sinwar assassination away from being able to declare a ‘victory’ over Hamas in Gaza.”

In this way, Israel’s latest assassination appears to be a calculated risk on behalf of Netanyahu, who very likely personally approved the [operation](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/08/01/world/middleeast/how-hamas-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-bomb.html)
 to kill Haniyeh. All rights reserved.

* * *

, [Transnational Threats](/topics/transnational-threats)

, and [Terrorism and Irregular Warfare](/topics/terrorism-and-irregular-warfare)

!Riley McCabe <image:4046>

[](/people/riley-mccabe)

### [Riley McCabe](/people/riley-mccabe)

Associate Fellow, Warfare, Irregular Threats, and Terrorism Program

### Programs & Projects

*   [Warfare, Irregular Threats, and Terrorism Program](/programs/warfare-irregular-threats-and-terrorism-program)
    
*   [International Security Program](/programs/international-security-program)
    
*   [Defense and Security](/defense-and-security) On the other, Haniyeh’s death delivers the Israeli government an important political victory that could open the door to reducing military operations in Gaza on its own terms.

Haniyeh had led Hamas’s political wing since 2017, serving as the group’s public face and overseeing its [finances](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2023/11/02/hamas-funding-ismail-haniyeh-us-sanctions/)
. Haniyeh was based in Qatar but was visiting Tehran for the inauguration of Iran’s new president when he was killed.

The assassination of Haniyeh is just the latest in a string of Israeli efforts to [hunt down](https://www.timesofisrael.com/in-recording-shin-bet-chief-vows-to-kill-hamas-chiefs-in-lebanon-turkey-qatar/)
 members of Hamas’s leadership for their involvement in the group’s attack on October 7, 2023. Still, there is always the risk that serious retaliation from Iran over Haniyeh’s assassination could tip the region into a broader war.

Haniyeh’s death also complicates peace talks over Gaza. In the near term, his assassination will undermine the [recent progress](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/28/world/middleeast/negotiators-meet-in-rome-to-revive-push-for-hostage-release-and-cease-fire-in-gaza.html)
 made between the two sides. Peace needs serious partners.”

However, in the long term, Haniyeh’s assassination and the killing of other senior Hamas leaders could serve as a path for Israel to reduce its military operations in Gaza. The assassinations of Haniyeh and Deif make this path appear increasingly credible."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS) published an article on August 1, 2024, discussing the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, the head of Hamas’s political wing, in Tehran on July 31, 2024. <image:4045>. The article mentions that the assassination was carried out by an explosion and that Iranian supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei vowed to avenge Haniyeh's death. The article also discusses the potential implications of the assassination, including the risk of broader war and the impact on peace talks.

Israeli hostage relative on her ‘worst fear’ after assassination of Hamas political leader

*   Hamas said its [political leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/07/30/middleeast/hamas-political-leader-ismail-haniyeh-killed-intl-hnk/index.html)
     in an Israeli strike in the Iranian capital of Tehran, a major development that throws the region into an unpredictable and dangerous new phase.
*   Israel has neither confirmed nor denied being behind Haniyeh’s assassination. headquarters in New York on November 27, 2023.

Kyodo/AP/File

Israel will not be invited to a ceremony in Japan commemorating the 1945 atomic bombing of Nagasaki city, according to Japanese news agency Kyodo News, which cited the city’s mayor Shiro Suzuki.

In June, Suzuki sent a letter to Israel calling for a ceasefire in Gaza, leaving an invitation to the annual peace ceremony on hold due to a risk of “unexpected situations” such as protests, according to Kyodo News.

At a press conference on Wednesday, Suzuki said he had not seen any changes that would lessen those risks ahead of the August 9 ceremony promoting world peace.

Israel’s Ambassador to Japan, Gilad Cohen, described the decision as “regrettable” in a post on X, adding it “sends a wrong message to the world.” 

In contrast, Hiroshima has invited Israel to its annual ceremony on August 6, a decision that’s been controversial with activists and atomic bomb survivors’ groups that say Israel should be excluded this year as Russia and Belarus have been for the past two years over Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine.

Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei speaks after casting his vote for the presidential runoff election on July 5 in Tehran, Iran.

Majid Saeedi/Getty Images/File

Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has issued an order for Iran to “strike Israel directly” following the killing of Hamas’ political leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran overnight, [according to the New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/31/world/middleeast/iran-orders-attack-israel.html)
. 

The Times, citing information it said was provided by three Iranian officials familiar with the order, said the directive was given during an emergency meeting for Iran’s Supreme National Security Council Wednesday. 

The New York Times said the officials asked not to be named because they did not have the authority to speak publicly. The report did not say how or when any strike would be carried out.

Earlier, Khamenei said it was Iran’s “duty” to avenge Haniyeh’s death since he was killed inside Iran. 

“You killed our dear guest in our house and now have paved the way for your harsh punishment,” he said in a statement, referring to Israel. 

[](mailto:?subject=New%20York%20Times%3A%20Iran's%20supreme%20leader%20orders%20direct%20attack%20on%20Israel%20after%20killing%20of%20Hamas%20leader&body=Checkout%20the%20latest%20news%20from%20CNN%3A%0Ahttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnn.com%2Fworld%2Flive-news%2Fhamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24%23h_a162d5f7f74543675685f7a84f72646d "Share with email")

Link Copied!

CNN reviewed statements by Hamas and others, in addition to state media outlets and other social media posts, to analyze and track the Islamist militant group leader Ismail Haniyeh’s movements since October 7, 2023.

After he celebrated seeing his fighters return to the Gaza Strip with Israeli equipment in Hamas’ office in Istanbul, Turkey on October 7, Ismail Haniyeh spent the majority of his time in Doha as head of Hamas’ Political Bureau but took a number of trips to Tehran, Istanbul and Cairo, according to a CNN analysis.

**Tehran:** Haniyeh took at least four trips to Tehran – in November, March, May and July. During all four visits, he met with Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei.

In May, he attended the funerals of Iranian president Ebrahim Raisi and foreign minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, who were killed in a helicopter crash. 

On his final trip to Tehran, which ended with his assassination, he was attending the inauguration of the new Iranian president Masoud Pezeshkian.

**Cairo:** He also took three known trips to Cairo in November, December and February, to lead Hamas’ ceasefire negotiating delegation. That negotiation process, which is still ongoing, has been shepherded by Qatar and Egypt.  

**Doha:** As war ravaged Gaza, Haniyeh spent the majority of his time in Hamas’ Doha offices. While there, press statements from Hamas indicate he repeatedly met with a number of foreign dignitaries, gave speeches and held meetings.

Doha is also where Haniyeh issued his first statement after his three sons, and four grandchildren were killed in Gaza by an Israeli airstrike. In that statement from mid-April, he said that such killings will only make Hamas more steadfast in its principles, adding that Hamas will not surrender, will not compromise, no matter how great the sacrifice.

![Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei speaks after casting his vote for the presidential runoff election on July 5 in Tehran, Iran. citizens who are already in Southern Lebanon, near the borders with Syria, and/or in refugee settlements to depart,” it said. 

The State Department had previously warned American against traveling to southern Lebanon, but the update to warning against travel to the entire country reflects the ratcheting up of tensions in the region.

The updated advisory comes a day after an Israeli strike on a Hezbollah commander in Beirut.

Link Copied!

A relative of a hostage still being held in Gaza has said it is “hard to see” how the assassination of Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh will help advance the deal to secure the release of the remaining hostages. 

Sharone Lifschitz, whose 83-year-old father Oded has been held in Gaza since October 7, said that she trusted statements from Qatari meditators on Wednesday warning that Haniyeh’s killing “doesn’t help” the talks between Israel and Hamas. 

She told CNN that her confidence is waning in the ability of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to broker a deal to return the hostages. Lifschitz’s 85-year-old mother was previously released from captivity in Gaza.

Netanyahu’s priority now, according to Lifschitz, is not securing the release of the hostages but rather shoring up his own “political survival.” She said she has “no sympathy” for Netanyahu himself, only for the hostages, their families, and the “innocent civilians caught up in this nightmare.” 

“Our loved ones are not here. In remarks Wednesday, a defiant Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to keep fighting, saying his country has delivered “crushing blows” to its enemies.

Haniyeh was the second figure of an Iran-backed group assassinated in the past day, following the killing by Israel of a senior Hezbollah commander in Lebanon.

Hezbollah has confirmed the death of senior commander Fu’ad Shukr.

 on Tuesday killed Shukr, whom it blamed for a deadly Saturday attack in the Israeli-occupied [Golan Heights](https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/28/middleeast/druze-golan-heights-israel-occupied-attack-explainer-intl/index.html)
.

The leader of the [Iran-backed paramilitary force](https://www.cnn.com/2023/10/19/middleeast/hezbollah-explainer-intl/index.html)
, Hassan Nasrallah, will issue a statement on Thursday at the funeral of Shukr, the statement added.

“As for our political position on this heinous attack and major crime, it will be expressed by the Secretary-General of Hezbollah Hassan Nasrallah tomorrow at the funeral procession for the martyred leader,” the statement said.

The military wing of Hamas said it had carried out “two shooting operations” near the city of Hebron in the occupied West Bank on Wednesday in response to the killing of the group’s political leader Ismail Haniyeh.  

The Al Qassam Brigades said it was “the beginning of a swift response to the cowardly assassination of our great national leader, the martyr Ismail Haniyeh.”

“Hebron will lead the way in carrying out qualitative operations in the coming days, by the will of Allah,” it added.

The Israel Defense Forces said a civilian was in the hospital after being shot at and stabbed northeast of Hebron.

Israel’s Magen David Adom (MDA) emergency service said a 50-year-old man was hospitalized in serious condition after being stabbed on Route 60 near Kiryat Arba, a settlement on the outskirts of Hebron."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The CNN article, updated August 1, 2024, reports that Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh was killed in an Israeli strike in Tehran on July 31, 2024. <image:26> The article mentions that Israel has neither confirmed nor denied being behind the assassination. The article also mentions that Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has ordered Iran to "strike Israel directly" following the killing of Haniyeh. The article also includes information about Haniyeh's movements since October 7, 2023, including multiple trips to Tehran.

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh): 
Content: The Wikipedia article discusses the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, the political leader of Hamas, in Tehran, Iran, on July 31, 2024. The attack, attributed to Israel, resulted in Haniyeh's death along with his personal bodyguard. The article mentions differing reports on the method of the attack, including a missile strike or a remotely detonated explosive device. The article also includes reactions from various parties, including Hamas, Iran, and Israel. <image:26> is not present in the article.


From [Source](https://www.csis.org/analysis/ismail-haniyehs-assassination-escalation-or-ramp):

The article mentions that the assassination was carried out by an explosion and that Iranian supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei vowed to avenge Haniyeh's death. The article also discusses the potential implications of the assassination, including the risk of broader war and the impact on peace talks.


From [Source](https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/hamas-political-leader-haniyeh-killed-iran-07-31-24):

* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

The killing of a top Hamas leader brings new uncertainties about cease-fire talks

**Hamas says Israel killed its top political leader while he was in Iran** **Hamas called Haniyeh's death "a dangerous event" that would have repercussions across the region. The prosecutor also seeks arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Israel’s defense minister.

Of Hamas’ top four leaders, only one may still be alive today: Hamas’ Gaza leader [Yahya Sinwar](https://www.npr.org/2023/12/03/1216138367/hamas-gaza-leader-yahya-sinwar)
.

[!The shadowy Hamas leader behind the war against Israel <image:5335>](https://www.npr.org/2023/12/03/1216138367/hamas-gaza-leader-yahya-sinwar)

### [Middle East conflict](https://www.npr.org/series/1205445976/middle-east-crisis)

### [The shadowy Hamas leader behind the war against Israel](https://www.npr.org/2023/12/03/1216138367/hamas-gaza-leader-yahya-sinwar)

In January, Hamas deputy chief Saleh al-Arouri was killed in a presumed Israeli strike in Lebanon.

This month, Israel said it killed Mohammed Deif, the head of Hamas’ military wing in Gaza, in an airstrike that killed scores of other Palestinians, though his fate is still unknown. **Vahid Salemi/AP** ****hide caption****

****toggle caption****

Vahid Salemi/AP

TEL AVIV, Israel — The Palestinian militant group Hamas accused Israel of killing its top political leader Ismail Haniyeh in an airstrike in Iran on Wednesday and called his death “a dangerous event” that would have repercussions across the Middle East. Haniyeh was in Tehran for the inauguration ceremony of new Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian.

Israeli officials said they had "no comment" when asked about the Tehran attack and have not taken responsibility for it, but previously had vowed to kill Haniyeh and other Hamas leaders after the militant group led a surprise Oct. It's very hard to speculate," Blinken said in an interview with Channel News Asia during a visit to Singapore.

The White House has no independent confirmation and cannot confirm reports that Israel had killed Haniyeh in Tehran, as Hamas claimed, National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby told reporters in Washington.

Haniyeh's killing threatens to escalate tensions across the Middle East. It also came just hours after Israel said it had killed a top commander of the Lebanese militant group [Hezbollah](https://www.npr.org/2024/07/30/1233941853/israel-hezbollah-beirut-lebanon-explosion-hassan-nasrallah)
 in an airstrike in the Lebanese capital of Beirut.

In a speech on Wednesday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told Israelis, “Challenging days are ahead.” He added that Israel was prepared for any threat and scenario.

Iran's president called Haniyeh's killing a "cowardly action" and said that Iran would defend its territorial integrity. In a statement on X, Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said there would be a “harsh punishment” for the assassination.

Qatar’s Foreign Ministry [condemned](https://mofa.gov.qa/en/statements/the-state-of-qatar-condemns-assassination-of-head-of-the-political-bureau-of-hamas)
 Haniyeh’s death and said it represented a “dangerous escalation” in the conflict. He was the principal point of contact for Hamas in talks brokered by Egypt and Qatar.

In a press conference from Gaza, Hamas Deputy Chairman in the Gaza Strip Khalil al-Hayya implied that talks would be stalled after the killing, saying, “There is no talk of negotiations in the shadow of blood.” But he stressed that Hamas’ goals for the negotiations had not changed, saying that Hamas “has set a clear path regarding the negotiations and the absence of one leader or another does not divert the movement's compass from its goals."

Netanyahu said Wednesday that for months people have been urging him to end the war. But \[Israel\] has managed to kill all possible paths to peace.”

In the West Bank’s largest city, Ramallah, resident Bahaa’ Zeit said he was saddened by the news, but shocked that Iran wasn’t able to do more to protect Haniyeh.

"How could Israel break through Iran’s skies and security and let a guest of their country get assassinated?" Zeit said.

Hamas leader Sami Abu Zuhri [told Al-Aqsa TV](https://t.me/SerajSat/218417)
 that Israel will not succeed in breaking the will of the Palestinian people and that Hamas is an ideology that will not fade.

“This occupation must realize that it opened fire on itself and not on Ismail Haniyeh,” Abu Zuhri said."

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/what-we-know-so-far-about-assassination-hamas-leader-2024-07-31/): 
Content: "Iran's Presidency /WANA (West Asia News Agency)/Handout via REUTERS/File Photo [Purchase Licensing Rights, opens new tab](https://www.reutersconnect.com/item/palestinian-group-hamas-top-leader-ismail-haniyeh-meets-with-iranian-president-masoud-pezeshkian-in-tehran/dGFnOnJldXRlcnMuY29tLDIwMjQ6bmV3c21sX1JDMks1OUFFR1JYTQ%3D%3D/?utm_medium=rcom-article-media&utm_campaign=rcom-rcp-lead)

DUBAI, July 31 (Reuters) - [Hamas](/world/middle-east/what-is-palestinian-group-hamas-2023-10-30/)
 leader [Ismail Haniyeh](/world/middle-east/obituary-tough-talking-haniyeh-was-seen-more-moderate-face-hamas-2024-07-31/)
 was assassinated early on Wednesday morning in Iran, the Palestinian militant group and Tehran said.

This is what we know about [the killing of Haniyeh](/world/middle-east/hamas-chief-ismail-haniyeh-killed-iran-hamas-says-statement-2024-07-31/)
, which was widely assumed to have been carried out by Israel though its government made no claim of responsibility and said it would make no comment on the incident.

Sign up [here.](undefined?location=article-paragraph&redirectUrl=%2Fworld%2Fmiddle-east%2Fwhat-we-know-so-far-about-assassination-hamas-leader-2024-07-31%2F)

DETAILS OF ASSASSINATION
------------------------

Iran's Revolutionary Guards confirmed the death of Haniyeh, who was the face of Hamas' international diplomacy as the war triggered by the Islamist group's attack on Israel on Oct. Media reports said he was referring specifically to the conflict between Israel and Lebanon's Iran-backed Hezbollah group that has ramped up since the outbreak of the Gaza war.

The prime minister of Qatar, which along with the United States and Egypt has acted as a mediator in Gaza ceasefire negotiations between Israel and Hamas, suggested that Haniyeh's killing could jeopardise efforts to secure a truce.

"Political assassinations and continued targeting of civilians in Gaza while talks continue lead us to ask: How can mediation succeed when one party assassinates the negotiator on other side?" Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani wrote on X.

Egypt's foreign ministry said Haniyeh's killing and the lack of progress in ceasefire talks complicated the situation.

The news - which came less than 24 hours after Israel claimed to have killed Hezbollah's top military commander whom it said was behind a deadly rocket strike in the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights on Saturday - appears to set back any chances of an imminent ceasefire agreement in the Gaza war.

At the same time, the risk of a war between Israel and Hezbollah has grown since the attack in the Golan that killed 12 children in a Druze village, and the air strike meant to kill senior Hezbollah commander [Fuad Shukr](/world/middle-east/who-is-hezbollah-commander-targeted-by-israel-beirut-2024-07-30/)
.

Hezbollah said [Shukr had been in a building](/world/middle-east/hezbollah-says-top-commander-was-building-targeted-by-israeli-strike-fate-2024-07-31/)
 in the southern suburbs of Beirut when it was targeted by Israel, but the group did not confirm his fate.

Still, a Hezbollah member of parliament said the heavily armed group would now be ready to fight a war with Israel.

The killing of its close ally Haniyeh on Iranian soil will put pressure on Tehran to react against Israel, which has been hunting Hamas leaders since militants stormed into Israel on Oct. [Skip to main content](#main-content)

!Palestinian group Hamas' top leader Ismail Haniyeh meets with Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian in Tehran <image:5340>

Palestinian group Hamas' top leader Ismail Haniyeh meets with Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian in Tehran, Iran, July 30, 2024. 7, killing 1,200 people and taking over 250 hostage, according to Israeli tallies.

In response, Israel launched a relentless ground and air offensive in densely populated coastal Gaza that has killed more than 39,400 people, according to Gaza health officials, and left more than 2 million facing a humanitarian crisis.

Haniyeh's assassination could also encourage Iran's proxies in the Middle East who support Hamas - Hezbollah, Yemen's Houthis and armed groups in Iraq - to seek revenge.

Iran will "defend its territorial integrity, dignity, honour, and pride, and will make the terrorist occupiers regret their cowardly act" of killing Haniyeh in Tehran, President Masoud Pezeshkian said on Wednesday.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:26> This image shows the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024. This is how a precision strike looks like: a single missile through the window, and only Haniyeh and his bodyguard are dead. Nobody else in the building is even injured."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:26>)
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The image <image:26>

## Elaboration
I am sorry, but I am unable to verify the claim. The evidence consists only of the image itself. I need additional information to verify the claim, such as news reports or other sources that describe the event.


## Actions
```
web_search("Ismail Haniyeh assassination July 31 2024")
web_search("Hamas leader killed July 31 2024")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran, Iran, on July 31, 2024. The attack, attributed to Israel, resulted in Haniyeh's death along with his personal bodyguard. The sources mention differing reports on the method of the attack, including a missile strike or an explosion.

The sources include reactions from various parties, including Hamas, Iran, and Israel. The Iranian supreme leader vowed to avenge Haniyeh's death and ordered Iran to "strike Israel directly". The image <image:26>

### Evidence from `web_search`
NPR reports that Hamas accused Israel of killing its top political leader Ismail Haniyeh in an airstrike in Iran on July 31, 2024. ([https://www.npr.org/2024/07/31/nx-s1-5058383/hamas-says-top-leader-killed-in-iran](https://www.npr.org/2024/07/31/nx-s1-5058383/hamas-says-top-leader-killed-in-iran)) Reuters reports that Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh was assassinated early on Wednesday morning in Iran on July 31, 2024. ([https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/what-we-know-so-far-about-assassination-hamas-leader-2024-07-31/](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/what-we-know-so-far-about-assassination-hamas-leader-2024-07-31/)) <image:5324>, <image:5325>, <image:5335>, <image:5340>


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim that the image shows the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh on July 31st, 2024, is supported by the evidence. Multiple sources confirm that Ismail Haniyeh was assassinated on that date. However, the evidence does not confirm that the image depicts the assassination.
